title: Protocol to purify and detect ubiquitinated phospholipids in budding yeast and human cell lines
procedures:
Step-by-step method details
Step-by-step method details
Preparation of total membranes from yeast and human cells
Timing: 2 h
This section describes the isolation of total membranes from 12-mL cultures of budding yeast and two 10-cm dishes of HeLa cells. To detect endogenous Ub-PE in 50 mL of yeast culture or ten 10-cm dishes of HeLa cells, use 5× volumes of buffers throughout the procedures described below.
Isolation of total membrane from yeast cells.
Resuspend cells in 500 μL of ice-cold disruption buffer containing protease inhibitor cocktail.
Transfer the cell suspension to a 2-mL tube (e.g., Watson Bio Lab, Cat# 1392-200) containing approximately 500 μL of 0.5 mm zirconium dioxide beads.
Disrupt cells using a multi-beads shocker (Yasui Kikai, 2700 rpm, 30 s on/30 s off, twice).
Remove intact cells, cell debris, and nuclei by centrifugation at 1,000 × g at 4°C for 5 min.
Collected 25 μL of the supernatant and mix it with 5 μL of 6× sample buffer (total lysate).
Apply the supernatant to ultracentrifugation at 100,000 × g at 4°C for 1 h. troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].
Remove the supernatant (the cytosol) and proceed to step 3.
Note: To efficiently recover the lysate at step d, puncture the bottom of the 2-mL tube using an 18-gauge needle, place it in a 15-mL tube, and carry out centrifugation.
Isolation of total membrane from HeLa cells.
Resuspend cells in 500 μL of ice-cold homogenization buffer.
Centrifuge at 4°C at 1,000 × g for 5 min.
Remove the supernatant, resuspend cells in 500 μL of ice-cold homogenization buffer containing protease inhibitor cocktail, and incubate on ice for 10 min.
Disrupt cells using a 27-gauge needle and syringe unit (20 strokes).
Centrifuge at 4°C at 1,000 × g for 5 min to remove intact cells, cell debris, and nuclei.

Collect 25 μL of the supernatant and mix it with 5 μL of 6× sample buffer (total lysate).
Apply the supernatant to ultracentrifugation at 100,000 × g at 4°C for 1 h. troubleshooting 3[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.5].
Remove the supernatant (i.e., the cytosol) and proceed to step 3.
Note: Cells can also be disrupted by nitrogen decompression (Parr Instrument Company, model# 4639 Cell Disruption Vessel, 500 psi).
Purification of hydrophobic proteins
Timing: 2 h
This section describes the purification of hydrophobic proteins by Triton X-114 phase partitioning. When performing the delipidation assay for verification of conjugation of ubiquitin to phospholipids, proceed to step 7 after completing this step (see also step 7 for details).
Purification and concentration of hydrophobic ubiquitin.
Resuspend the pellet (i.e., membranes) in 200 μL of ice-cold Triton X-114 buffer containing protease inhibitor cocktail.
Centrifuge at 4°C at 16,900 × g for 10 min to remove the insoluble fraction.
Transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5-mL tube.
Place the tube at 37°C for approximately 1 min (until the solution becomes cloudy).
Centrifuge at 25°C at 16,900 × g for 10 min.
Remove the top layer (i.e., the aqueous phase, approximately 180 μL in the first round and 500 μL in the wash steps).
Add 500 μL of Triton X-114 wash/dilution buffer and mix well.
Place the tube on ice until the solution becomes clear (within several min).
Repeat steps 3d–3h twice (for a total of three repetitions of wash steps). troubleshooting 4[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.7].
After the third repetition of wash steps, add 500 μL of Triton X-114 wash/dilution buffer containing a proteinase inhibitor cocktail to the detergent phase.
Place the tube on ice until the solution becomes clear (within several min).
Centrifuge at 4°C at 16,900 × g for 10 min to remove debris.

Transfer approximately 520 μL of the supernatant to a new 1.5-mL tube.
Proceed to step 4 or 5.
Note: Buffers containing Triton X-114 separate into the detergent and aqueous phases above the cloud point (approximately 23°C) and become cloudy.
Purification of hydrophobic ubiquitin
Timing: 1 day
This section describes the purification of hydrophobic ubiquitin by immunoprecipitation with anti-FLAG antibody (step 4) and pull-down with ubiquilin 1 ubiquitin-associated domain (UQ1 UBA)9[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib9] (step 5).
Immunoprecipitation of 3xFLAG-Ub with anti-FLAG antibody
Wash anti-FLAG M2 affinity beads with 1 mL of Triton X-114 wash/dilution buffer three times.
Add 20 μL of anti-FLAG M2 affinity beads (50% in Triton X-114 wash/dilution) to the sample.
Incubate at 4°C for 12–18 h using a rotator.
Wash the beads with 500 μL of Triton X-114 wash/dilution buffer three times.
Wash the beads with 500 μL of ddH2O twice.
Proceed to step 6 or add 50 μL of 1× sample buffer and proceed to step 8.
Note: To spin down the beads, centrifuge at 4°C at 1,000 × g for 1 min.
Pause point: After mixing with 1× sample buffer, the samples can be stored at −20°C until until proceeding to SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting.
Purification of endogenous ubiquitin using GST-UQ1 UBA
Add 20 μL of GST-UQ1 UBA immobilized on glutathione Sepharose (50% in Triton X-114 wash/dilution buffer).
Incubate at 4°C for 12–18 h using a rotator.
Wash the beads with 500 μL of Triton X-114 wash/dilution buffer three times.
Wash the beads with 500 μL of ddH2O twice.
Proceed to step 6 or add 50 μL of 1× sample buffer and proceed to step 8.
Note: UQ1 UBA preferentially captures oligo- and poly-ubiquitin rather than mono-ubiquitin.
Pause point: After mixing with 1× sample buffer, the samples can be stored at −20°C until until proceeding to SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting.

Verification of conjugation of ubiquitin to phospholipids by phospholipase D
Timing: 1.5–2.5 h
To verify that ubiquitin is conjugated to phospholipids, the sensitivity of hydrophobic ubiquitin to phospholipase D (PLD) can be tested. This section describes on-bead PLD treatment and a delipidation assay using the Triton X-114 fraction in step 3. In the delipidation assay, the purified Triton X-114 fraction is incubated with PLD and subjected to another round of phase partitioning (Figure 2[href=https://www.wicell.org#fig2]). After PLD treatment, delipidated ubiquitin species are remobilized from the Triton X-114 to the aqueous fraction, while hydrophobic proteins (e.g., ubiquitinated membrane proteins) remain in the Triton X-114 fraction.
imgsrc:https://prod-shared-star-protocols.s3.amazonaws.com/protocols/2268-Fig2.jpg
Figure 2. Procedure of the delipidation assay
The Triton X-114 fraction is incubated with phospholipase D (PLD) followed by another round of phase partitioning. Delipidated ubiquitin (Ub) species migrate from the Triton X-114 to the aqueous fraction, while hydrophobic proteins remain in the Triton X-114 fraction.
Treatment of immunoprecipitated hydrophobic ubiquitin with phospholipase D.
Wash the beads with 200 μL of PLD buffer.
Add 50 μL of 1 unit/μL PLD in PLD buffer to beads.
Incubate at 30°C with shaking at 1200 rpm for 1 h.
Wash the beads with 200 μL of ddH2O.
Add 50 μL of 1× sample buffer and proceed to step 8.
Pause point: After mixing with 1× sample buffer, the samples can be stored at −20°C until until proceeding to SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting.
Delipidation assay.
Perform Triton X-114 phase partitioning as described in step 3.
After the third repetition of wash steps, add 500 μL of PLD buffer instead of Triton X-114 wash/dilution buffer to the detergent phase.
Add PLD at 1 unit/μL.
Incubate at 30°C for 1 h.
Centrifuge at 25°C at 16,900 × g for 10 min.

Transfer approximately 500 μL of the top layer (the aqueous phase) to a new 1.5-mL tube and add 5 μL of 100x protease inhibitor cocktail.
Add 500 μL of Triton X-114 wash/dilution buffer to the bottom layer (i.e., the detergent phase).
Place the tube on ice until the solution becomes clear (within a couple of min).
Place the tube at 37°C for approximately 1 min (until the solution becomes cloudy).
Centrifuge at 25°C at 16,900 × g for 10 min.
Remove the top layer.
Add 500 μL of Triton X-114 wash/dilution buffer containing protease inhibitor cocktail.
Centrifuge at 4°C at 16,900 × g for 10 min to remove debris.
Transfer the supernatant to a new 1.5-mL tube.
Purify ubiquitin from the samples in steps 7f and 7n as described in step 4 or 5.
SDS-PAGE and immunoblotting
Timing: 2 days
This section describes the detection of Ub-PE by immunoblotting. To detect endogenous ubiquitin, we use anti-ubiquitin monoclonal antibody (clone VU-1), which sensitively detects mono- and poly-ubiquitin.10[href=https://www.wicell.org#bib10] This antibody requires pretreatment of a transferred membrane with 0.5% glutaraldehyde.
SDS-PAGE.
Load 2 μL of the total lysates and 15 μL of the affinity-purified samples and run them on a 15% gel. troubleshooting 5[href=https://www.wicell.org#sec6.9].
Transfer proteins to a poly (vinylidene fluoride) (PVDF) membrane with 0.2-μm pore size.
Immunoblotting.
Detection of 3xFLAG-Ub by anti-FLAG antibody.
Incubate the membrane in 5% skim milk/Tris buffered saline with Tween 20 (TBST) for 1 h.
Incubate the membrane with anti-FLAG (dilution, 1/2000) in 5% bovine serum albumin (BSA)/TBST at 4°C for 12–18 h and proceed to step 9c.
Detection of endogenous ubiquitin by anti-Ub antibody.
Wash the PVDF membrane with PBS for 2 min three times.
Incubate the membrane in 0.5% glutaraldehyde in PBS at 22°C–25°C for 20 min.
Wash the membrane with PBS three times.

Incubate the membrane in 5% skim milk/TBST for 1 h.
Incubate the membrane with anti-Ub (dilution, 1/500) in 5% BSA/TBST at 4°C for 12–18 h and proceed to step 9c.
Incubation with a secondary antibody and detection.
Wash the membrane with TBST for 5 min three times.
Incubate the membrane with horseradish peroxidase-conjugated anti-mouse IgG (dilution, 1/5000) in 5% skim milk/TBST 22°C–25°C for 1 h.
Wash the membrane with TBST for 5 min four times.
Develop using Immobilon western chemiluminescent horseradish peroxidase substrate.
Acquire images using a Fusion Solo 7S system (Vilber).
